name: market for sodium sulfate, anhydrite | sodium sulfate, anhydrite | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/256/documentation

This is a market activity. Each market represents the consumption mix of a product in a given geography, connecting suppliers with consumers of the same product in the same geographical area. Markets group the producers and also the imports of the product (if relevant) within the same geographical area. They also account for transport to the consumer and for the losses during that process, when relevant.;This is the market for  'sodium sulfate, anhydrite', in the Global geography.;Transport from producers to consumers of this product in the geography covered by the market is included.;'sodium sulfate, anhydrite'  is an inorganic substance with a CAS no. : 007757-82-6. It is called 'disodium;sulfate' under IUPAC naming and its molecular formula is: Na2O4S. It is solid under normal conditions of temperature and pressure , it appears as a white crystalline solid with no distinct odor, which is soluble in water. It is modelled as a pure substance. On a consumer level, is used in the following products: washing & cleaning products, plant protection products and cosmetics and personal care products. There is no publicly available information about the consumption of this substance on industrial sites.

This activity starts at the gate of the activities that produce 'sodium sulfate, anhydrite',  within the geography of Global.

This activity ends with the supply of 'sodium sulfate, anhydrite',  to the consumers of this product. Transport is included. Product losses during transportation are assumed negligible and are therefore not included.

exchanges.description:
The total marine transport volume differentiated into major commodity groups based on data from FearnResearch (2001): Fearnley's Annual Review 2000. Oslo: Fearnley/AS, p. 1-78. The category “Other cargo” accounts for 38% of total maritime transport volume and has been distributed on commodity groups based on the proportions of transport by rail and inland waterways.
The total marine transport volume differentiated into major commodity groups based on data from FearnResearch (2001): Fearnley's Annual Review 2000. Oslo: Fearnley/AS, p. 1-78. The category “Other cargo” accounts for 38% of total maritime transport volume and has been distributed on commodity groups based on the proportions in the marine import and export of the US in 2001-2010.
